title: Understanding $$f(x-h)$$
text: For some value $$h$$, $$f(x-h)$$ means that f(x) is translated to the right by $$h$$ units. Similarly, $$f{\left(x+h\right)}$$ means that f(x) is translated to the left by $$h$$ units.

title: Understanding $$f(x-h)$$
text: Since $$h$$ is $$2$$, $$f(x-2)$$ means that the graph is translated right by $$2$$.

title: Understanding $$h f{\left(x\right)}$$
text: For some value $$h$$ not equal to $$0$$, $$h f{\left(x\right)}$$ means that f(x) is stretched vertically by $$h$$. Similarly, $$\frac{f{\left(x\right)}}{h}$$ means that f(x) is compressed vertically by $$h$$.

title: Understanding $$h f{\left(x\right)}$$
text: Since $$h$$ is $$3$$, $$3f{\left(x-2\right)}$$ means that the graph is stretched vertically by $$3$$.

title: Does Order Matter?
text: The order of transformation does not matter if each transformation is performed independently on the input (within the paranethesis of the function) and output (outside the paranethesis of the function).

title: Does Order Matter?
text: Is the translation right performed on the input or output of the function?

title: Does Order Matter?
text: Is the stretch vertically performed on the input or output of the function?

title: Does Order Matter?
text: Since the transformations were performed independently of each other, the order does not matter.
